case_name: Firestone Tyre & Rubber Co. Ltd. v. Subramaniam

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 515 of 1966 was filed by special leave from the Award dated November 23, 1964, of the Labour Court, Andhra Pradesh in Industrial Dispute No. 5 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 515 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 23, 1964, of the Labour Court, Andhra Pradesh in Industrial Dispute No. 5 of 1964. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, Rameshwar Nath, Mohinder Narain and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: The dismissal of Subramaniam, van driver employed by Firestone Tyre Rubber Co. P Ltd., was set aside by the Labour Court, ordering reinstatement without back wages.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal arises from the award of the Presiding Officer, Labour Court, Andhra Pradesh, Hyderabad, by which the dismissal of one Subramaniam, van driver in the employ of the Firestones Tyre Rubber Co.  P  Ltd., after a domestic enquiry was set aside and the Company was ordered to reinstate him but number to pay him his back wages.

facts.text: The reference was made by the Government of Andhra Pradesh on February 7, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The reference in which this decision was rendered was made by the Government of Andhra Pradesh on February 7, 1964. The following are the circumstances leading up to it. Subramaniam was a van driver with the Firestone Tyre Rub- ber Co. from 1953.

facts.text: Subramaniam was employed as a van driver by Firestone Tyre Rubber Co. from 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Subramaniam was a van driver with the Firestone Tyre Rub- ber Co. from 1953. One of his duties as a van driver was the transportation for delivery of the products of the Company.

facts.text: On May 28, 1963, Subramaniam set out to deliver tyres covered by six invoices to diverse addresses.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1963, Subramaniam set out to deliver tyres companyered by six invoice . s to diverse addresses. Two of the invoices  Nos. 13815 and 13816  were companycerned with eight tyres  4 tyres per invoice  of the specification 8.25 x 20 Tran. H.D.Nyl. 12-PR.

facts.text: Invoices Nos. 13815 and 13816 covered eight tyres (4 per invoice) of specification 8.25 x 20 Tran. H.D.Nyl. 12-PR.

anchor.surface_text: Two of the invoices  Nos. 13815 and 13816  were companycerned with eight tyres  4 tyres per invoice  of the specification 8.25 x 20 Tran. H.D.Nyl. 12-PR. Subramaniam took delivery of the tyres and signed the six invoices.

facts.text: Subramaniam took delivery of the tyres, signed the six invoices, locked them in his van with a key which never left his possession.

anchor.surface_text: Subramaniam took delivery of the tyres and signed the six invoices. After locking the tyres in his van with a key which he claims never left his possession, he set out with one M. V. Das  packer scooter driver  by his side in the drivers cabin.

facts.text: Subramaniam set out with M.V. Das (packer scooter driver) by his side in the driver's cabin soon after lunch break.

anchor.surface_text: After locking the tyres in his van with a key which he claims never left his possession, he set out with one M. V. Das  packer scooter driver  by his side in the drivers cabin. This was soon after the lunch break.

facts.text: At about 3.15 p.m. on May 28, 1963, Subramaniam telephoned the company office that two tyres from the two invoices were short.

anchor.surface_text: This was soon after the lunch break. At about 3.15 p.m. Subramaniam telephoned to the office of the Company that two tyres from the two invoices were short. He was asked to return at once.

facts.text: Upon return, the tyres in the van were unloaded and counted, short by two; stock check showed no excess.

anchor.surface_text: He was asked to return at once. On his return the tyres with him were unloaded and companynted. By way of an immediate check the tyres held in stock were also companynted. There was numberexcess in stock. The tyres in the van were short by two.

facts.text: Subramaniam claimed the tyres were shortloaded or lost/stolen on the way.

anchor.surface_text: The tyres in the van were short by two. Subramaniam maintained that numbertyres were lost or stolen on the way. His case was that the tyres were shortloaded.

facts.text: After investigation, a charge-sheet was served on Subramaniam for theft, fraud or dishonesty.

anchor.surface_text: Subramaniam maintained that numbertyres were lost or stolen on the way. His case was that the tyres were shortloaded. After investigation, a charge-sheet was served on him for the following act of misconduct- Theft, fraud or dishonesty in companynection with the employers business or property.

facts.text: Subramaniam was suspended pending the result of the enquiry held by Mr. R. M. Coyajee, Industrial Relations Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet gave full details and fixed the time and place of an enquiry to be held against him, and further informed him that he companyld defend himself through a workman, produce evidence or cross-examine the witnesses. He was suspended pending the result of the enquiry.

facts.text: Enquiry held: four witnesses for Company, two for Subramaniam; Company filed 20 documents, Subramaniam 2.

anchor.surface_text: The enquiry was held by Mr. R. M. Coyajee, Industrial Relations Officer. Four witnesses for the Company and two for Subramaniam were examined. The Company filed 20 documents and Subramaniam filed 2 documents.

facts.text: Mr. Coyajee found the charge proved and submitted minutes to superior officers.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Coyajee found the charge proved and submitted the minu- tes of the enquiry to the Superior officers. Then the Manager, Southern Division informed Subramaniam that he was companyvinced of. the latters guilt and that he had tentatively decided to dismiss him.

facts.text: Manager informed Subramaniam of guilt, tentatively decided dismissal, asked to show cause; Subramaniam replied but was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Then the Manager, Southern Division informed Subramaniam that he was companyvinced of. the latters guilt and that he had tentatively decided to dismiss him. He asked Subramaniam to show cause, if any, against this decision, Subramaniam showed cause but the Manager ordered his dismissal.

facts.text: Tyre and Rubber Companys Employees Union raised dispute, referred to Tribunal on whether dismissal justified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tyre and Rubber Companys Employees Union having raised a dispute the matter was referred to the Tribunal , a  whether the dismissal of Shri K. Subramaniam, van Driver by the employers of Firestone Tyre Rubber Co.  P  Ltd., Hyderabad is justified? If number, to what reliefs is he entitled?

facts.text: Labour Court held enquiry opposed to natural justice, conclusion perverse, charge not proved, ordered reinstatement without back wages.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Tribunal the Union companytended that the enquiry was opposed to the principles of natural justice and the companyclusion was perverse. The Tribunal held that the enquiry was number held properly and the companyclusion arrived at the domestic enquiry was perverse.

facts.text: Subramaniam wrote letter dated May 30, 1963, claiming shorter number of tyres supplied than in invoices.

anchor.surface_text: They have referred to the workmans letter dated May 30, 1963 in which he reiterated that he was supplied a shorter number of tyres than that given in the invoices and to his statement before Mr. Coyajee that he would state his case fully.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the domestic enquiry was properly conducted and did not offend principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the enquiring officer afforded every opportunity to Subramaniam to companytrovert or prove his case. Subramaniam was informed of the charge very clearly, the witnesses were examined in his presence and be was allowed to cross-examine them fully.

facts.text: Company's evidence of loaders supported that 8 tyres were loaded, Subramaniam signed invoices after checking.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, the Management refused to believe Subramaniam even though he was supported by Das. This the Management was entirely within its right in doing and the Tribunal was in error in exercising appellate powers by companying to a different companyclusion.

facts.text: Das supported Subramaniam that no tyres lost during journey, implying 6 tyres loaded.

anchor.surface_text: As to the evidence of Das it is obvious that Das was supporting Subramaniam in his statement that numbertyres were lost during the journey which supported the version that 6 tyres instead of 8 were actually loaded.

facts.text: Appeal succeeds, no order as to costs; company will not ask return of wages paid during pendency.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore succeeds and will be allowed but in the circumstances of the case we make numberorder about companyts. On behalf of the Company it was stated that the amount paid to the workman during the pendency of the appeal as part of the wages will number be asked to be returned.
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated November 23, 1964, of the Labour Court, Andhra Pradesh in Industrial Dispute No. 5 of 1964.

Before the Tribunal the Union contended that the enquiry was opposed to the principles of natural justice and the conclusion was perverse. The Tribunal held that the enquiry was not held properly and the conclusion arrived at the domestic enquiry was perverse.

arguments.claim: No principle compels calling for explanation before charge-sheet after preliminary enquiry showing prima facie fault

anchor.surface_text: As regards ground No. (a) it is clear to us that, although it may be desirable to call for such an explanation before serving a charge-sheet. there is no principle which compels such a course.

arguments.claim: Procedure of examining delinquent first permissible without prejudice, especially where accusation based on record or admitted facts; not ipso facto vitiating

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, wise to ask the delinquent whether he would like to make a statement first or wait till the evidence is over but the failure to question him in this way does not ipso facto vitiate

holdings.text: There is no principle which compels calling for an explanation before serving a charge-sheet after a preliminary enquiry where prima facie fault exists.

anchor.surface_text: As regards ground No. (a) it is clear to us that, although it may be desirable to call for such an explanation before serving a charge-sheet. there is numberprinciple which companypels such a companyrse.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirable to seek explanation to potentially avoid enquiry but not mandatory; charge-sheet permissible on prima facie case without fishing for defence.

holdings.text: Domestic enquiries cannot be equated to enquiries under Article 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal equated the domestic enquiry to enquiries under Art. 311 of the Constitution which was hardly proper.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 311 applies to government servants; private employment domestic enquiries have different standards.

holdings.text: The enquiring officer afforded every reasonable opportunity to the workman to defend himself, satisfying principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the enquiring officer afforded every opportunity to Subramaniam to companytrovert or prove his case. Subramaniam was informed of the charge very clearly, the witnesses were examined in his presence and be was allowed to cross-examine them fully.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workman informed of charge, cross-examined witnesses, led evidence, shown findings for show cause; full defence conducted.

holdings.text: Failure to ask the delinquent whether to make a statement first or after evidence does not ipso facto vitiate the enquiry unless prejudice is shown.

anchor.surface_text: It is, however, wise to ask the delinquent whether he would like to make a statement first or wait till the evidence is over but the failure to question him in this way does number ipso facto vitiate the enquiry unless prejudice is caused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wise practice but not mandatory; applies precedents distinguishing cases on record/admitted facts vs disputed; no prejudice here as prior statement given.

holdings.text: Examining the delinquent before management evidence is permissible where no prejudice caused, especially on record facts.

anchor.surface_text: It is only when the person enquired against seems to have been held at a disadvantage or has objected to such a companyrse that the enquiry may be said to be vitiated. It must, however, be emphasised that in all cases in which the facts in companytroversy are disputed the procedure ordinarily to be followed is the one laid down by this Court in the cited cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes strict precedent rule for disputed facts; permissible for record/admitted matters or to narrow issues; no disadvantage shown, prior version given.

holdings.text: The Labour Tribunal cannot exercise appellate powers by re-appreciating evidence or substituting its findings on merits for those of the domestic enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal was in error in exercising appellate powers by companying to a different companyclusion. All that the Tribunal could do was to see that the enquiry was properly conducted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's role limited to checking enquiry fairness; management entitled to credibility choices (e.g., loaders over workman/Das).

holdings.text: The domestic enquiry was properly conducted and did not offend principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the enquiry was properly companyducted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Addressed all tribunal grounds; opportunities given, no prejudice, procedure fair despite sequence.

holdings.text: The dismissal of the workman is justified.

anchor.surface_text: a whether the dismissal of Shri K. Subramaniam, van Driver by the employers of Firestone Tyre Rubber Co.  P  Ltd., Hyderabad is justified? If number, to what reliefs is he entitled?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry proper, tribunal exceeded scope; management's findings on charge stand.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed, Labour Court award set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore succeeds and will be allowed but in the circumstances of the case we make numberorder about companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry valid, tribunal erred; restores dismissal order.
